Jaws literally hit the floor when Lady Gaga hurled herself off the roof of Houston‚Äôs NRG Stadium at yesterday's Super Bowl. Lady Gaga's Super Bowl trickery UP NEXT VIDEO Lady Gaga's Super Bowl trickery. Source: Twitter Lady Gaga's Super Bowl trickery 
Fans looked on in awe as the kooky singer, surrounded by glittering drones in the colours of the American flag, blasted out a line from the Pledge of Allegiance before plunging a whopping 79 metres down to pitch level. 
But it turns out the impressive feat was actually a trick of the eye. Gaga started her performance on the roof before flying down to her stage. Source: Getty But it turns out the leap was more of an illusion. Source: Getty 
Why? Because Gaga actually filmed the breath-taking plunge back on January 30, when it's likely her fall from the roof was broken by a net just out of sight. 
Producers then simply merged that footage with the live recording of her being lowered into the stadium to kick start her epic performance. 
The game was up when people who were actually there took to social media to confirm that from their perspective, the show began with Gaga suspended in the air, as opposed to with the roof jump. Footage from inside the stadium shows Gaga dangling mid-air. Source: Twitter 
And Intel Drones general manager Natalie Cheung has revealed that from a "logistics and creative perspective", filming the eight-second fall and then expecting Gaga to launch into a 13 minutes performance just wasn't realistic. 
"It‚Äôs a bit hard for her to go from the roof all the way down to the floor of the stadium," she told USA Today , adding that the weather also played a part.

We‚Äôd hate to plan all this and, if the wind speeds are too high or if it‚Äôs raining and the roof is closed, no one can see this spectacular show,‚Äù she said. Gaga took it down a notch to sing her balled "Million Reasons". Source: Getty 
But despite the trickery, the world nonetheless went gaga for Gaga's killer half-time performance at the 2017 Super Bowl. 
Taking to social media, fans were quick to praise the 30-year-old American singer, with one tweeting: "Lady Gaga is slaying".
